column1: Palm Desert is a city in Riverside County
column4: in the Coachella Valley

column6: 121 miles (194 km) northeast of San Diego and 122 miles (196 km) east of Los Angeles. The population was 48

column17: Palm Desert is a popular retreat for "snowbirds" from colder climates (the Eastern and Northern United States
column19: who swell its population by an estimated 31
column20: 000 each winter. Palm Desert has seen more residents become "full-timers"

column1: The area was first known as the Old MacDonald Ranch
column2: but the name changed to Palm Village in the 1920s when date palms were planted. Local historians said the main residents of pre-1950 Palm Desert were Cahuilla Indian farmers of the now extinct San Cayetano tribe
column3: but a few members of the Montoya family of Cahuilla/Spanish descent were prominent leaders in civic life.The first residential development occurred in 1943 in connection with an Army maintenance camp in the area. That site was later developed into "El Paseo"
column4: an upscale shopping district not unlike Rodeo Drive. In 1948
column5: the Palm Desert Corporation began to develop real estate
column6: and in 1951 the area was given its present name.

column1: The elevation (City hall) is 224 feet (68 m) above sea level. Elevations vary from the lower northern half once covered in sand dunes to the upper slope southern cove (300–900 feet or 91–274 metres) all the way to the ridgeline at 1
column2: 000 feet (over 300 meters). Palm Desert is located in the Coachella Valley
column3: the north-western extension of the Sonoran Desert.

column2: California lies on the northern side of Interstate 10 from Palm Desert itself

column1: The climate of the Coachella Valley is influenced by the surrounding geography. High mountain ranges on three sides and a south-sloping valley floor all contribute to its year-round warm climate
column2: with the warmest winters in the western United States. Palm Desert has a tropical desert climate: Its average annual high temperature is 89 °F (32 °C) and average annual low is 62 °F (17 °C)
column3: but summer highs above 108 °F (42 °C) are common and sometimes exceed 120 °F (49 °C)
column4: while summer night lows often stay above 82 °F (28 °C). Winters are warm with daytime highs between 73–84 °F (23–29 °C). Under 5 inches (130 mm) of annual precipitation are average
column5: with over 348 days of sunshine per year. The mean annual temperature at 75.8 °F (24.3 °C) makes Palm Desert one of the warmest places in the United States. The hottest temperature ever recorded in Palm Desert was 125 °F (52 °C) on July 6
column6: 1905. The surrounding mountains create a thermal belt in the southern foothills of Palm Desert
column7: leading to a micro-climate with significantly warmer night-time temperatures during the winter months. The University of California maintains weather stations located in this thermal belt as part of their ecological project in the Philip L. Boyd Deep Canyon Desert Research Center.

column1: Rapid growth and several annexations in the 1980s and 1990s have made Palm Desert a major shopping destination and the main center of business activity in the Coachella Valley. The city has evolved as a major shopping destination following the development of Westfield Palm Desert which opened in 1983. This development was followed by One Eleven Town Center
column2: Town Center Plaza and Desert Crossing which included Target and other national anchors. The expansion of Fred Waring Drive into a six-lane thoroughfare has also encouraged new retail centers and commercial zones.

column1: El Paseo Drive is downtown Palm Desert's main shopping street. The area around the street has evolved into an upscale shopping district featuring 150 boutiques
column3: and restaurants. El Paseo is often compared to Beverly Hills' Rodeo Drive due its concentration of posh retail outlets and lush landscaping. The street runs parallel to State Route 111
column4: which serves as the main surface thoroughfare from Palm Springs to Indio.

column1: Golf – Palm Desert is home to about 30 golf courses.
Tennis – tennis courts in the Marrakesh and Shadow Mountain golf clubs.
The city's first golf course and tennis club was Shadow Mountain in 1952
column3: the Palm Desert Greens mobile home park golf course in 1961
column4: and the Palm Desert Country Club in 1962. The latter
column5: located five miles (8 km) east of the original city
column6: was formally annexed in 1992. The total number of golf clubs (more than 30 located within 10 miles (16 km) from the city) have made Palm Desert known as the "World's Golf Capital."

column1: Desert Willow Golf Resort is the City Of Palm Desert's municipal golf course
column2: and has two championship courses: Mountain View and Firecliff. It is associated with the Westin Desert Willow Resort at the golf course location. The Firecliff course is listed at #13 in Golf Magazine's 'Best Courses you can Play' 2010 list for California.
a spate of private golf clubs

column6: since lodging and hospitality is a major portion of the local tourist-based economy.

column1: Palm Desert was incorporated as a city in 1973 and designated a charter city in 1997. It operates on a council-manager form of government. Residents of Palm Desert elect five non-partisan council members who serve four-year staggered terms
column2: with elections occurring every two years. The position of mayor is non-elected and rotates annually among the members of the city council. The council serves to pass ordinances
column4: and hire the city manager and city attorney. The city manager oversees administrative operations and the appointment of department heads.

column1: The Riverside County Sheriff's Department has a station located in Palm Desert which provides police services to the municipalities of Palm Desert
column4: as well as the surrounding unincorporated areas.

column1: The city of Palm Desert contracts for fire and paramedic services with the Riverside County Fire Department through a cooperative agreement with CAL FIRE. Palm Desert currently has three fire stations
column4: Station 67 (Mesa View)
column5: and Station 71 (North Palm Desert). Each fire station provides an engine company and a paramedic ambulance. Fire station 33 also has a truck company.

column1: Palm Desert is the home of the Living Desert Zoo and Gardens
column2: a combination zoo and botanical garden featuring an extensive collection of desert plants and animals and a state-of-the-art animal hospital.

column1: Palm Desert is also the site of the main campus of College of the Desert
column3: which has expanded greatly in size since the campus opened in 1961 and one of the buildings was built by donations from the local Cahuilla Indian tribal nations. The state higher education system opened an extension campus duplex (the Indian Wells Education Center for both California State University
column4: San Bernardino and the University of California Riverside.

column4: Jimmy Carter and Ronald Reagan. The northernmost part of Palm Desert is served by the Palm Springs Unified School District

column6: or Nellie Coffman Middle School and Cathedral City High School in Cathedral City
column7: California. Some students in the eastside are zoned to La Quinta High School and Colonel Mitchell Paige Middle School.

column1: The city is home to the Palm Desert Scene
column2: a musical genre that has been heavily influential internationally since the early 1990s. Many of the Palm Desert bands are credited for starting the rock/metal subgenre known as stoner rock. Bands including Queens of the Stone Age
column4: and Eagles of Death Metal have become well known rock bands.
